sentence: During interphase, the cell grows and DNA is replicated.
We should note, however, that interphase and mitosis (kayrokinesis) may take place without cytokinesis, in which case cells with multiple nuclei (multinucleate cells) are produced.
The final preparations for the mitotic phase must be completed before the cell is able to enter the first stage of mitosis.

Prophase (the â€œfirst phaseâ€ù): the nuclear envelope starts to dissociate into small vesicles, and the membranous organelles (such as the Golgi complex [Golgi apparatus] and the endoplasmic reticulum), fragment and disperse toward the periphery of the cell.
Microtubules that will form the mitotic spindle extend between the centrosomes, pushing them farther apart as the microtubule fibers lengthen.
These microtubules overlap each other midway between the two poles and contribute to cell elongation.
Astral microtubules are located near the poles, aid in spindle orientation, and are required for the regulation of mitosis.
Each chromatid, now called a single chromosome, is pulled rapidly toward the centrosome to which its microtubule is attached.
Although the stages of mitosis are similar for most eukaryotes, the process of cytokinesis is quite different for eukaryotes that have cell walls, such as plant cells.
During interphase, the Golgi apparatus accumulates enzymes, structural proteins, and glucose molecules prior to breaking into vesicles and dispersing throughout the dividing cell.
During interphase, the Golgi apparatus accumulates enzymes, structural proteins, and glucose molecules prior to breaking into vesicles and dispersing throughout the dividing cell.
Enzymes use the glucose that has accumulated between the membrane layers to build a new cell wall.
Some cells enter G0 temporarily due to environmental conditions such as availability of nutrients, or stimulation by growth factors.
